title: mps do have the power to stop a no deal brexit jeremy hunt admits
story: After two humiliating defeats for the PM this week, the Foreign Secretary said it was looking less likely that Parliament would allow us leave the bloc with no agreement in place.The PM was slapped down on Tuesday and Wednesday night when MPs voted to restrict tax powers in a No Deal situation, and then again to force her to come back to the Commons within three daysher deal gets rejected next week.Today Mr Hunt admitted that MPs were wrestling back control of the Brexit process and the numbers for next week were looking challenging.He told BBC Radio : I think its now looking much less likely that Parliament would allow a no-deal outcome anyway.We have seen from this week that Parliament has the ability to assert itself and to shape outcomes.And he warned thatthe deal gets rejected then it could lead to Brexit paralysis and maybe we wouldnt leave at all.He said that failing to deliver on the vote would be incredibly damaging and politicians would come to regret it for many, many generations.MPs should come together and get behind the deal as its the only one on offer, he stressed.Meanwhile the EUs Jean Claude Juncker said he was talking to No about what clarications on Brexit they want.He said it should not be confused with a renegotiation.Sources said that they were expecting a reassurance on Monday, ahead of the vote on Tuesday.The PM has been reaching out to Labour MPs and union leaders to try and get them on side.But even senior figures are privately admitting that defeat is ahead - possibly the biggest ever government loss.

title: dancing on ice gemma collins
story: “Fatberg. Right ahead.”Then we all sat and waited for the impact that would surely follow.And waited . . . and waited, as Gemma remained stubbornly upright for the duration.Such is le at Dancing On Ice, “the show where anything could happen”, according to the continuity announcer, but never actually does.That’s the main reason why people stopped watching and ITV buried it in a cold and shallow grave five years ago.Then, without much warning or any great demand, it was suddenly brought back to le, last year, and proved every bit as underwhelming and injury free as I remembered.There’s no horse too dead for another ITV flogging, though, so it’s just ed for yet another run, with most of the same fixtures and fittings.Phillip Schofield and Holly Willoughby do a solid enough job of hosting, considering their script could suck a black hole inside out, and there’s a four- man Ice Panel where the truth bombs are exclusively supplied by Jason Gardiner, who arrived dressed as Bret Maverick for Sunday’s opening show.What seems to separate this year’s Dancing On Ice from almost every other series, however, is the line-up. It’s actually quite imaginative and offers the show a serious chance of redemption,just one of them can be hospitalised before the end of the run.Among the  contenders, we’ve got: Westle’s Brian McFadden, Richard “Hollywood is the catalyst for everything I do” Blackwood, cricketer Ryan Sidebottom, and Saira Khan, who was advised by Ruth Langsford to “do Strictly”, but is a bit too low rent for the BBC so is stuck here wearing skates and tights.Despite having two hours to fill, none of that lot actually got to dance on Sun- day, though, as, I suspect, ITV wanted to clear the decks for its preferred bookings.These include -year-old Didi Conn , from Grease, Corrie’s Jane Danson, who was put in “a horse lt, with half rotation”, and Mark “Joe Mangel” Little, who’s turned into Dog The Bounty Hunter since we last saw him on Neighbours.But let’s not kid ourselves here. The reason many of us probably tuned in, on Sunday, in was to see Gemma Collins.Towie’s self-styled “GC” the first letter of which stands for Gigantic. A woman who really could do with a heavy landing on that over-entitled a**e of hers or, better still, developing a work ethic and some humility.I prayed for the worst then, and saved what was left for her partner, Matt Evers, but he’d clearly taken one look at Gemma and thought “screw that for le without a disability allowance”.There were no lts, no falls and she didn’t even have the decency to rip her drawers when she tried the splits. Sunday was just another entry in DOI’s endless list of crushing disappointments.Partly thanks to some very sympathetic marking, from everyone except Jason, Gemma will also get to skate again in a fortnight, which, I think I’m right in saying, means they’ll have to make an attempt at the infamous “King Kong lt”.And then, once Addison Lee has dropped her off at the rink, it’s on with the skating.Piers Morgan: “I bumped into Gemma Collins in Langan’s restaurant, at Christmas, and . . . ”A “She’s OK, actually.”B “A Japanese sports network bought the footage for million yen.”THE expression TV gold doesn’t begin to do justice to BBC’s fly-on-the-wall documentary about Matt and Luke Goss’s O reunion gig.It’s a genuine masterpiece that would deserve to be mentioned in the same breath as Spinal Tap,the pair of them weren’t so wonderfully serious about everything.Bros: After The Screaming Stops is the title of the film, directed by David Soutar and Joe Pearlman, who had the good sense just to point their cameras at the boys and let them say things like: “I made a conscious decision, because of Stevie Wonder, not to be superstitious.” “Rome wasn’t built in a day, f*** me that’s true, but we don’t have the time Rome did.” “He was a rectangle, I was a rectangle and together we made a square, which is a fortress.” And “There were  one-way streets and one solitary two-way street, where me and my brother met in the middle.” .As well as all the tortured metaphors and Matt’s profundities, though, the film also features a fantastically earnest rant about conkers and an escalating feud between the boys, which should have had every single viewer crying out for both of them to be included in the next I’m A Celebrity line-up, pretty much from the word go.But how did I feel at the end of this emotional dual carriageway In the words of poet philosopher singer Matt Goss: “Two words. Privileged.”John Humphrys: “At least  of the  books of the New Testament are usually attributed to which author ”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “New Year’s Day in the UK, January or December ”Lauren: “December.”And Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In , Mark Calaway, who’s better known as The Undertaker, retired from which sport ”Gerry: “Golf.”The Voice UK fooling me into thinking it might go a whole episode without Jenner Hudson “spontaneously” bursting into song.Luther turning out to be a soulless, unpleasant, far-fetched mess. The insane pouting contortions of Candice “Bake Off” Brown during Celebrity Mastermind.The BBC somehow crowbarring an anti-Brexit dig into The Greatest Dancer.And Dee Dee Wilde calling her old Tena Lady troop, on the same show, Pan’s Fans, rather than the far more appropriate and eye-catching Pads People. Basic stuff, really.Steve Howey: “You need to have experienced that experience to have the experience.”And Phil Thompson: “All these City players are like for like. Even Danilo, who isn’t as good as Kyle Walker.”JUST when they thought we couldn’t send them anything worse than the potato famine, up pipes Last Leg Of The Year guest Sue Perkins with this Brexit bonus: “My New Year’s resolution is to try and track down a dim and distant Irish relative, so I can finally get that passport.”Andthere are any genealogists who can help, send the information to me marked “Generation Game: Urgent.”Knighthood’s in the post.Paul Ryan’s Farage cameo on Brexit: The Uncivil War.Clarkson not trying to be likeable, on Millionaire, which, ironically, made him very likeable.Bradley Walsh hating every second of his skye on ITV’s Breaking Dad.Simplicity Cremations’ perfectly-placed advert during The Last Leg Of The Year .And Billy Connolly, overwhelmed by love, on BBC, paying tribute to: “All the things that made me good and bad, Scotland.”Match Of The Day’s Jonathan Pearce on Alo Morata: “He needs to do that game in, game out to prove he’s good enough for Cha.”“They need to do that gay men, gay marriage to prove he’s good enough for Cha.”Sent in by Iain Milne, Newcastle. Picture research: Amy Reading.TV dramatists haven’t yet rewritten the result of Brexit.But, trust me, they will eventually. This is just the start of the softening-up process.Brexit: The Uncivil War, a Channel  production that toyed with neutrality, for about  minutes, but had given up any pretence long before the drama’s rather desperate postscript finally stopped trying to nudge viewers in the Remainer direction.The two main characters weren’t entirely subtle either.One, played by Benedict Cumberbatch, was Dominic Cummings, the hi-vis dork who was in charge of the Leave campaign.The other, “I’M IN” leader Craig Oliver, whose portrayal, by Rory Kinnear, as a brilliant-but-tragic hero, was rather undermined by the fact Craig Oliver was also one of the drama’s political advisers.What saved The Uncivil War, though, was the acting, particularly Paul Ryan’s Nigel Farage turn, and Cumberbatch, who wasn’t a perfect fit for Cummings as his Durham accent slipped too often.It’s a performance brimming with such mesmerising charisma, though, I can genuinely see The Uncivil War effecting genuine change – two extra zeroes on Dominic Cummings’ next salary.Such is the real power of TV drama.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grieving mum reveals moment anxiety
story: NewsGrieving mum reveals moment her anxiety-ridden son, , was found dead near homeAnn Marie Grocott of Silverdale found the body of Jordan Taylor in an old railway tunnel after three days of searchShareCommentsByTfany Lo:,  JAN NewsJordan Taylor, , had been reported missing on Easter Sunday last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mother has spoken of how she found her missing sons body in a disused railway tunnel - just minutes from their home. Ann Marie Grocott of Silverdale, Newcastle-under-Lyme, had reported her -year-old son, Jordan Taylor, missing on Easter Monday last year when he failed tohome from a weekend with friends. Ms Grocott and other relatives searched an old railway tunnel after receiving no news in three days. They found the teenagers body lying in a tunnel - covered in mud - with his shoes and mobile phones discarded nearby.   Jordans death remained a mystery in between the moment he left a house party on the night of April  - Easter Sunday - and the discovery of his body on April , an inquest heard. Ms Grocott revealed that Jordan had suffered from anxiety and depression since leaving school and had barely left the house for  months, reported StokeonTrent Live . Since being prescribed medication, the youngsters situation had improved and had started to socialise with friends. Its reported that Jordan left his home in Sneyd Terrace, Silverdale, on March , and intending to stay a friends over the weekend. According to Ms Grocott, she received messages from Jordan every day but heard nothing after Sunday lunchtime. She reported him missing on Easter Monday and police sent out helicopters to search for Jordan.   On Thursday, April , Ms Grocott and close family members went to look on land off Pepper Street, where the old railway tunnel is situated. We went on the tracks and walked towards the tunnel, she said.Me and my sister were looking up the sides of the tunnel. I saw his shoe first, up the side of the bridge. Then I heard my name being shouted. I turned and Jordan was there. Staffordshire Police launched an investigation into the death of Jordan as they interviewed people who had been with Jordan over the weekend. However, there was no evidence of third-party involvement in his death. It is believed the teen was last seen alive on Easter Monday when a resident of Coppice Avenue saw a youth thought to be Jordan reclined on top of the tunnel. Pathologist Dr Alexander Kolar concluded Jordan died from hypothermia and there were no evidence showing Jordan had been assaulted upon the post-mortem examination results. A high level of beta hydroxybutyrate was found in Jordans body, which indicated he had a previously undiagnosed problem with his insulin problems. Dr Kolar explained hypothermia can lead to severe confusion and sufferers can undress themselves believing they are feeling hot - which could explain why Jordan was not wearing his shoes. The test also revealed the teen had amphetamine and ecstasy in his system and he had also taken cocaine.   The level of drug was not toxic, but would have been important in whats taken place, Dr Kolar said. Iniduals that have taken drugs are more vulnerable to developing hypothermia - they are more likely to put themselves in situations that are not advisable, and drugs have an effect on the way the body regulates its own temperature. The cause of death was recorded as hypothermia, possibly diabetes-related, with a background of MDMAand amphetamine use. North Staffordshire coroner Ian Smith recorded a conclusion of misadventure in Jordans death. He said: “Jordan was a vulnerable, naiumlve young lad in a situation where he did things because others were doing it. I think that’s the reason he took the drugs. “He left the house where he had been on Sunday night. No-one saw him leave. In his drug-affected state he left behind his bag. “He was seen in the area near his home on Monday. Why, oh why, did he not go home  The only explanation is the effect of the drugs and then the hypothermia, which has created this very confused state of mind. He has remained there until his body has given up at some stage.”

title: 5 universal credit changes announced
story: News Universal Credit changes announced TODAY - and  injustices that still havent been fixedTory DWP chief Amber Rudd admitted parts of the system are not "compassionate" as she unveiled a major shake-up. Heres whats been announced, how it hits you - and why critics say it doesnt go far enoughShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video amber-rudd-announces-universal-credit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA string of Universal Credit changes have been unveiled today in a bid to save the six-in-one benefit from disaster. Tory Amber Rudd admitted parts of the system are not compassionate as she announced changes to the two-child limit, payments to landlords and the movement of millions of claimants. The Work and Pensions Secretary also promised action in the future on inequalities that its claimed hand all the money - and power - to domestic abusers. But with million people set to be on Universal Credit with no transition payments by Christmas, unions, charities and Labour blasted her for not going far enough. So what has actually been announced today, how will it hit you, and where does it fall short  Heres a guide to five big things that have been announced - and five injustices still in the system.  things that ARE being fixed . A poundm extension of the two child limit is being scrapped  A wicked cut hitting , families a year will be cancelled in a U-turn - three weeks before it was due to take force. Tory welfare chief Amber Rudd announced she is axing an extension of the two-child limit that was set to kick in on February . The policy stops parents claiming Tax Credits or Universal Credit for more than two children - a cut of up to pound, per child. It applies to children born after the cut took effect in April  - but from February was due to apply retrospectively, hitting children born before the cut was dreamed up. That extension has been scrapped, putting poundmillion back in claimants pockets over three years. BUT HERES THE CATCH: Amber Rudd faced fury for keeping the two-child limit overall - claiming it is fair. The Institute for Fiscal Studies - which has warned the policy would hurl , children into poverty - said the long-term impact will be the same because eventually all children will be born after . By the mid-s, the IFS believes it will cut , families benefits. UNISON general secretary Dave Prentis said: “The two-child limit is morally wrong and should be scrapped for everyone.Kate Henderson, Chief Executive of the National Housing Federation, said: “These families will still be just as vulnerable to falling into poverty as those who are now being exempted. This policy causes real hardship for thousands of people, and we would urge the Secretary of State to remove the cap altogether. Labour shadow work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said: “This partial U-turn does not go far enough. She added: The Government must stop the [UC] roll out immediately before more people are pushed into financial hardship.  Changes will be brought in later this year to ensure the UC payment goes directly to a familys main carer more often. Amber Rudd said she had listened to arguments that the one payment per household system punishes women. By paying men in a household, UC can allow domestic abusers to have a financial grip over their partner. Women can never be truly free until they have economic independence, the top Tory said. I am looking at what more we can do to enable the main carer to receive the UC payment. An [I] will begin to make those changes later this year. Womens Aid said it was a step in the right direction to empowering more women to safely escape domestic abuse. BUT HERES THE CATCH: This solution stops short of the automatic split payments that many womens refuge payments have demanded. And Ms Rudd has not actually said what the changes will be, or exactly when theyll be brought in. . More people will have rent paid directly to their landlord  More UC claimants will have their rent paid directly to their landlord out of their benefits through a new online system. It comes after a torrent of complaints that people received too little benefits to pay their rent, and faced eviction. Ms Rudd said: One third of UC claimants in social rented housing have their rent paid direct to the landlord. But in the private sector that numbers only %. People in the private rented sector already face a far higher risk of losing their tenancy. And I know from talking to claimants and landlords that the current system isnt working for some of them. So we need to make it easier for tenants in the private sector to find and keep a good home by giving landlords greater certainty that their rent will be paid. Therefore Ive asked the department to build an online system for private landlords so they can request where necessary for their tenants rent to be paid directly to them. Chris Town, Vice Chair of the Residential Landlords Association hailed the decision. BUT HERES THE CATCH: The online system will only be optional for landlords, we dont know exactly when or how itll launch or what itll be like, and online benefit portals have a history of foul-up and failure. . Youll be able to get paid more than once a month  At the moment, most UC claimants are paid monthly which is meant to mirror the world of work. But after years of complaints, Ms Rudd finally admitted today: For others this approach does not work. Managing their money month to month can be challenging, even impossible. That could cause dficulties for people who are already vulnerable and Im determined to do more to help those claimants. So Jobcentres are now being asked how we can improve the provision of more frequent payments for new claimants, she said. Pilots will start shortly and then rolled out further once we have evidence of what works. BUT HERES THE CATCH: There is, again, no detail of how this help will work. She also referred to new claimants, which raises the question of what happens to people already on UC. . You might not be forced to pay for childcare up-front  UC claimants with childcare costs get % of them funded. But they have to pay up-front - leaving many turning to food banks. Today Ms Rudd admitted: I recognise this can cause financial dficulty, with some claimants struggling to pay up front or report their costs on time. So she has asked Jobcentres to make two changes. First,the first months childcare costs prevent a claimant from starting work, that claimant should be supported through jobcentres Flexible Support Fund. Second, Jobcentres should be flexible when parents are unable to report their childcare costs immediately. BUT HERES THE CATCH: Asking Jobcentres to show flexibility and discretion is a policy thats been fraught with problems in the past. If someones treated more unfairly in Watford than Leicester, could they complain the DWP is being unfair   things that ARENT being fixed . The -week wait for payment ISNT being cut  Amber Rudd rowed back sharply on claims she could cut the five-week wait people face for their first UC payment. She had hoped to cut it back - but today claimed Im satisfied with what weve got. Citing advance loans and run-on payments she said: I think we have addressed some of the key elements. But Im going to keep an eye on it because I recognise the most important thing in Universal Credit is that people have confidence in the system but also they get the money early enough. She added: At the moment Im satisfied with what weve got but Im going to keep it under review to see that we are addressing peoples needs for getting their money as early as possible. . The benefit freeze WONT end early  Ms Rudd said shed like to end the four-year benefit freeze - which has cut almost poundbn a year from families pockets - in spring . But thats just when it was due to end anyway. And she admitted: I havent had any further conversations with the Chancellor so Id better not say anything too definitive at this stage. Campbell Robb, Chief Executive of the independent Joseph Rowntree Foundation, said: The benefits freeze continues to be the single biggest policy sweeping families into poverty.If the Government is serious about being on the side of low-income families they will take immediate action to end this freeze one year early. Lib Dem MP Christine Jardine said: Instead of putting the most vulnerable in society through another  months of misery, Rudd should end the benefits freeze immediately. . Shes insisting UC wont actually be delayed  Amber Rudd confirmed she is delaying a vote by MPs on moving million existing benefit claimants to Universal Credit. MPs will approve only , trial cases for managed migration from this summer, with a full vote to be held at a later date. The Tory welfare chief said: Im not going to be rushed into the mass migration of existing claimants onto Universal Credit. My priority is to ensure the transition is done well. But Ms Rudd has insisted there will be no overall delay.Evenits pushed back, everyone will be moved over by .Secondly, youll STILL move overyou have a change of circumstances - see below... . The number of people on UC will double this year  Therell be million people on UC by Christmas - more than doubling the number on the benefit this year. Of those, hundreds of thousands will be existing benefit claimants who move over because they have a change of circumstances. Unlike the group thats being held back, they wont get any transition payments. Challenged by the Mirror, Ms Rudd was unable to say this decision was compassionate. Instead she said: The overall product that is Universal Credit is absolutely compassionate. . Workers are still being left out of pocket While Ms Rudd was giving her speech, four working single mums won a High Court challenge over Universal Credit. The women argued that a fundamental problem with the scheme means their monthly payments y enormously and they end up out of pocket. Two judges in London announced on Friday that the women - who say they are struggling financially because of the way the system operates - had succeeded in a judicial review action against the Work and Pensions Secretary. The ruling is a huge embarrassment for the government. The women challenged the method used by the Department for Work and Pensionswhen calculating the amount payable when their income changes month to month. Margaret Greenwood, Labour’s Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary, said: “It’s a disgrace that four single mothers have had to take the Government to court because of the impact that Universal Credit has had on their lives.“The Tories must stop the roll out of Universal Credit to ensure no more people are plunged into poverty and deprivation.” Asked about the case Ms Rudd said: Youll have to bear with me, Im not going to reply in full to that yet. Im going to have to consider it in the department and then well be coming forward with what our response is going to be.

story: NewsTesco and MS stockpile for Brexit as shops warned to hire extra security staffReports suggest the police are advising retailers to consider hiring extra security guards in the event of a no-deal BrexitShareByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsM and S are unable to stockpile fresh food which makes up % of their products "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTesco and Marks  Spencer have become the latest big names to reveal they are stockpiling packet and tinned foods in preparations for No Deal Brexit. According to thethe Tesco chief executive, Dave Lewis, said: “We looked at the lecycle and production of product categories that matter most to customers and sat down with all suppliers to discuss their production capability, where they hold stock andwe can help them hold it. It’s not possible to do that sort of thing on fresh food, so that’s where the pinch point would bethere were to be a no-deal.” MS chief executive Steve Rowe said: “We have taken some additional long-le stuff but our food business is % fresh and anything that slows down will contribute to cost and waste.” It comes as Politico reports that police are advising retailers to consider hiring extra security guards in the event of a no-deal Brexit. story: NewsBritains burglary hotspot postcodes revealed with affluent town topping listHenley-in-Arden, Warwickshire, tops the list of most burgled areas of the country while Whitehaven, Cumbria, has the lowest burglary rateShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsHenley-in-Arden is a quiet market town in Warwickshire - and also a burglary hotspot, data shows "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UKs burglary hotspots have been revealed in a huge study into crime across the country. title: devastating photos show how parents
story: NewsDevastating photos show how parents spent  days with their dead baby girlWARNING UPSETTING IMAGES: Heather Jordan, , from Cornwall is seen cuddling and playing with her stillborn babyShareCommentsByJames Somper:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsHeather and dad Lee played with Maranella and held her before her funeral "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother spent nine days living with her dead baby girl where she sang songs and danced with her. Heather Jordan, , gave birth to little Maranella at  weeks after she suffered an irritable uterus. Heartbreakingly, she was stillborn in December . But thanks to a cooling cot, Heather and dad Lee spent over a week with their dead daughter. This allowed them to play with and hold her before her funeral. Despite their daughters death, the full-time mum and her husband still treat Maranella as one of their three children. They still buy her presents and make her cakes on special occasions. Heather, from West Looe, Cornwall, said: Being able to spend time with her meant everything to me.   From the moment I saw her my heart filled with love. She was one of the most beautul children in the world. I was dazed. It was very surreal. She looked like she was sleeping like an angel. I want Maranellas memory kept alive. I dont want anyone  going through the same situation to feel as isolated and misunderstood as I did. This shouldnt be taboo. Shes my daughter and shell always have a special place in my heart regardless of what has happened.  Heather had a dficult pregnancy and was diagnosed an irritable uterus at  weeks. After being rushed to hospital at  weeks, Heather was given the devastating news that Maranellas heart had stopped beating and she would have to give birth to her stillborn daughter. Heather spent five agonising hours in labour before giving birth to her dead child.   She said: It was the worst experience Ive ever had in my le. Nothing can ever compare to it. I was focused on trying to deliver her healthy, despite being told she had died. I didnt really believe it until she came out and didnt cry. After the birth, Heather and Lee, a taxi driver, were moved to a bereavement suite in the hospital and were given a cold cot.  They then spent  hours with their daughter in the suite before taking her to the funeral home where they cuddled, held and sang to her, including Paul Wellers Wishing on a Star. Heather said: The nurses brought in the cold cot and told us we were able to spend as much time with her as possible. We sung with her and danced with her.   We tried to make memories and to do the things that any parent would do with their child. We sang Paul Wellers Wishing on a Star which is something I listen to nowIm especially missing her. Maranella was then moved to a funeral home where she spent her final seven days in a funeral home in order to prevent her skin from deteriorating. Heather said: We went into see her each and every day. We sang to her, looked at her and held her and tried to savour every second we had. We didnt want to take her out the cold cot for too long so we stayed inside with her for most of the time. It was beautul, savouring every second with her and seeing how she looked.  The people who helped us plan Maranellas funeral went above and beyond to give us everything we wanted for our baby girl. Heather and her husband still mark Maranellas birthday each year and included her in their celebrations this Christmas. Heather said: Shell forever be our little girl and well love her always. To donate towards Maranellas headstone, please visit the GoFundMe page here.

story: NewsFly-tippers leave UK streets a disgusting mess as crackdown brings new finesPictures from across the country show piles of waste - from dirty mattresses to industrial waste - dumped by those who apparently couldnt be bothered to dispose of it properlyShareCommentsByChris kitchingNada Farhoud:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror video industrial-lorry-tips-waste-torridon-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese shocking photos reveal the disgusting state of Britains streets thanks to fly-tippers who are illegally dumping rubbish at great cost to taxpayers. story: NewsHuge increase in flu as number of cases doubles to  MILLION in one weekThe number of people suffering from flu is on the rise as the outbreak takes hold of the UKShareByLaura Forsyth:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video everything-you-need-know-flu-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe number of cases of flu across the country have doubled to two million in a week, according to figures released today. People are being urged to get themselves vaccinated after health bosses confirmed that this winters influenza virus has begun. This comes after weeks of very little activity being reported by Public Health England . Millions are suffering symptoms such as a fever, chills and body aches and experts fear that this could put pressure on the already stretched NHS. The virus is now circulating widely across the UK and within the space of a week, cases have risen by  per cent in England and by  per cent in Wales. Meanwhile reports of the flu have risen by  per cent and by  per cent in Northern Ireland. PHE publishes a weekly report showing the number of flu symptoms that have been recorded in GP consultations.   Based on how often flu symptoms are reported per , patients each country sets its own criteria on what it considers to be an epidemic. While none of the home nations have reached the point of being an epidemic yet, England and Wales are in the “low” threshold. This is the second step on a five-point scale towards “very high” which are epidemic levels. Meanwhile in Scotland and Northern Ireland, levels are at the first threshold, which is baseline. The North East, West Midlands, North West England and Yorkshire and Humber have a “medium intensity” of cases, making it the worst affected. London, the South East, East Midlands, South West and East of England are less affected and are at “low intensity”. Regional figures are not available for Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland. Rates are at their worse since monitoring began in September and over three months  people have died of the illness. PHE figures released today revealed that the UK had one average  flu diagnoses per , people last week. And it showed that the HN strainwas the most widespread.  In the previous week there was a  per cent rise, which was the final week of . PHE added that the increase of cases means that the flu is having a “moderate impact” on hospitals and intensive care units. One third of this season’s flu cases that needed treatment intensive care happened last week - which is  of a  total. PHE is advising anyone who is eligible to get the flu jabthey have not already. For the first time this winter, all primary school children are now eligible for a free nasal spray flu vaccine as well as children aged two and three years old on August , . The vaccine is also being offered to staff working in residential care and nursing homes this winter who have regular client contact.   In addition carers, volunteers providing care or providing first aid in organised public events, as well as community first responders, are entitled to the vaccine. And adults who are morbidly obese – with a body mass index of  or more – can also have a jab for free. Those not eligible for a free NHS vaccine – such as healthy adults – can pay for one at their local pharmacy for between pound and pound. To improve effectiveness dferent flu vaccines recommended for dferent age groups are being introduced this year. There are four dferent types in total – one for children , two for adults under  years old, and one for those aged  and above.If you think you have flu, check out the symptom checker at www.nhs.uk conditions flu.

title: new mum left carrying intestines
story: NewsNew mum left carrying own intestines in shower after c-section scar burstWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES Mel Bremner, , bent down to pick up shampoo while she was in the shower and her guts spilled outShareCommentsByLaura ElvinLaura Elvin:,  JAN NewsMel Bremner, , admits she has a high pain threshold "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a new mum was left cradling her own intestines - after her c-section scar burst open five days following birth. First-time mum Mel Bremner, , bent down to pick up the shampoo in the shower when she saw her guts spill out. She hobbled to the sofa with the help of partner Aidan Johnson, , who covered her with a towel while the paramedics rushed to their home. Mel - who admits she has a high pain threshold - posed for a photo while they waited, before being airlted to hospital.She shared the photo with parenting site ChannelMum in a bid to dispel the myth that c-sections are easy and encourage mums to heed advice to take it easy after the major surgery.  Brave Mel, a hotel waitress from Macduff, Aberdeenshire, said: When I look at that photo I remember sitting there and my stomach and insides were literally in my hands. It was all gurgling around and moving. It was awful. I was sitting there thinking oh my god Im holding my intestines. It was quite creepy. Everyone was asking me what have you been doing  but I wasnt doing anything I shouldnt have - I was just having a shower. People think that c-section is the easy way out. Its really not. Its major surgery, but they dont tell you that at the time. They just tell you take it easy and away you go home.   I think after giving birth you are sort of expected to get up and get on with it. People are always telling you to take it easy but you just say Im fine. Mel had an emergency c-section on December , , after she was overdue, and she wasnt dilating despite medical intervention. The procedure at Dr Grays Hospital in Elgin seemed to go smoothly, and she was soon home with daughter Nadie, and partner Aidan, an off-shore engineering consultant. She said her surgery wound dressing was inspected before she left hospital, and she was deemed well enough to leave. Her partner noticed two white blobs in the middle of the wound four days after the birth - now thought to be fat - but they didnt suspect anything was wrong.   A day later she was in the shower when she bent down and the wound burst. I had only been in for a couple of minutes and I bent down to get the shampoo, she said. I dont rememberI felt it happen or saw it happen first, but my intestines were slipping out of my stomach. I put my hands underneath to catch it. I realisedI shouted out it would put pressure on my stomach, and thatI shout it will all fall out, so I was just trying to call out calmly to Aidan. He calmly led her from the shower to the sofa in the living room, propped up her feet and fetched a towel to cover her while calling for an ambulance. She said the pair contemplated covering her with cling film, but waited for paramedics who then called the air ambulance to take her to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary.   I dont think the woman on the end of the phone believed him really, she said. I was sat there holding my insides the whole time. I darent move my hands. She had surgery and after a couple of days in hospital was home again. The couple said the c-section consultant later speculated he had cut the end of the thread too short while stitching her up, or not tied the knot tight enough. Mel later had daughters Allie, now four, and Robyn, now three, by c-section, despite the traumatic experience with Nadie, now seven. She added: If Aidan had panicked I think I would have too, but he was brilliant and calm. A spokesperson for Dr Grays Hospital declined to comment.

title: oxford university professor defends himself
story: NewsOxford University professor defends himself against homophobia claimOxford professor, John Finnis has defended himself against allegations of homophobia after  students signed a petition calling for him to be removed from teachingShareCommentsByAndrew WoodcockRosie Dowsing:,  JAN NewsOxford professor John Finnis has defended himself against claims hes homophobic "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Oxford professor has hit back against against claims hes homophobic as a petition signed by  students called for him to be removed from teaching. John Finnis, a professor of law and legal philosophy for  years, says he has “absolutely” no hatred towards gay people. But the petition claims the professor has “a long record of extremely discriminatory views”. Some also argued his involvement in the university was discriminatory towards those who feel uncomfortable attending his classes. The protest picks up on one of the professor’s papers, published  and again in , in which he states homosexuality is “never a valid, humanly acceptable choice and form of le.”   Prof Finnis, who is emeritus professor of law and legal philosophy at University College, allegedly wrote that homosexuality is “destructive of human character and relationships. “It treats human sexual capacities in a way which is deeply hostile to the self understanding of those members who are willing to commit themselves to real marriage.” But the -year-old Roman Catholic told BBC Radio ’s Today programme that the paper is about “freewheeling heterosexual sex le” such as adultery and premarital sex, which he strongly disagrees with. In the  reprint of the paper he included a summary stating those who “accommodate” wild behaviour of this kind but support restrictions on homosexuality are “morally inconsistent.” “The summary ends by saying that those people who wink at heterosexual lestyles of a free-wheeling kind and on the other hand support restrictions on homosexuals are morally inconsistent, they are discriminatory, they are unfair, and it’s a deplorable view” said Prof Finnis.   Askedhe had hatred towards gay people, the professor said: Absolutely not. I have friends and my family have friends. We benefit from them. “They are good people and hatred is not on the scene. He also said that those who feel uncomfortable in his classes do not have to attend, because they are not compulsory. “No-one has to do that course or go to the seminars that I do with colleagues in the law faculty.” The professor said the allegations were just “a mixture of muddle and misrepresentation”, adding that he is no longer employed by the University and only teaches certain courses when invited to.

story: NewsThe lesaving food that most of us arent getting enough ofThis cheap and widely available food can be easily found in the supermarketShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDietitians are urging people across the UK to eat more fibre "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere is a superfood that Brits are not eating enough of that can increase le expectancy, say nutritionists. Dietitians are urging people across the UK to eat more fibre, which is neglected in around  percent of the populations diet. Eating wholegrain foods which contain dietary fibre could reduce the risk of contracting a range of deadly diseases including diabetes and cancer, a study has concluded. The risk of contracting a wide range of communicable diseases, including heart disease, could fall by as much as a third with a diet containing grains, pulses and wholegrain bread. Experts from the University of Otago in New Zealand and the University of Dundee say people should be eating around g of fibre a day. A team looked at clinical trials and studies conducted over the last four decades involving more than a million people with the findings published in the Lancet.   For every , participants in the  studies and trials, the impact of consuming higher fibre intakes translates into  fewer deaths and six fewer cases of coronary heart disease when compared to those consuming lower fibre diets. Dr Andrew Reynolds, lead author of the study, says the results showed there was clear evidence people should increase their intake of fibre. He said: Our research indicates we should have at least  to  grams of fibre from foods daily, although most of us currently consume less than  grams of fibre daily.  The study was commissioned by the World Health Organisation which is looking at the development of new recommendations for optimal daily fibre intake. Co-author professor Jim Mann said: This study is essential as there is increased public confusion over what to base our meal choices on, and the impact our dietary choices have on our risk of certain diseases.   Researchers also found people who increased the amount of fibre in their diet had lower body weight, and total cholesterol. Prof Mann said: We also found an overwhelmingly positive effect, with high fibre diets being protective against heart disease, diabetes, cancers and measures of mortality. story: NewsBest pasta sauce in the world contains just three ingredients – and one might surprise youLegendary cookery writer Marcella Hazans celebrated recipe also does away with the need for choppingShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorJoshua Barrie:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror lestyle video best-pasta-sauce-world-contains-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen it comes to quick weeknight dinners theres nothing easier than a bowl of pasta and some tasty tomato sauce. Whether you add extra ingredients to it to make it a bit fancier or have it as it is, its a go-to for people up and down the country. But the jars of ready made sauce many of us have at the back of the cupboard for emergencies can be packed full of sugar, and Dolmio maker Mars Food once insisted its sauces are only eaten once a week. Uncle Bens too. But according to Italian American food writer Marcella Hazan, a good pasta sauce is remarkably simple and economical, too. Much cheaper than buying jars.   Marcella, who died in , was born in Cesenatico, Italy, in  and went on to open a New York cookery school and write hugely respected cookbooks. In one of them, Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking, Marcella advises using only three ingredients in tomato sauce: onion, butter, and tinned tomatoes. Thats it. How much butter, you ask  A generous knob. The  recipe is still revered by food writers and cooks alike. No chopping is required. And pasta and tomato sauce is always a hit round the family dining table. Marcellas precise instructions are to put half a peeled onion into a pot with butter and tinned tomatoes and to leave it all to simmer for  minutes. Food publication Delish dubbed the sauce the best in the world. Her husband Victor talked to Epicurious about her efficient methods: Marcella was a genius when it came to taste. She had an immediate understanding about how flavour affects a dish. Marcella Hazan favoured ease and efficiency   She asked herself, Why chop an onion  Why saute  Im going to put the onion, tomato, and butter together and forget about it. Is it really the best in the world  Its a bold claim and a subjective one. But Italians are famous for their simplicity in cooking. Its all about the produce – tomatoes being one of the most important. No other preparation is more successful in delivering the prodigious satisfactions of Italian cooking than a competently executed sauce with tomatoes, Marcella says in her book. Her sauce is very rich. Others favour dferent techniques. Jamie Oliver adds four cloves of garlic and garnishes with fresh basil. BBC Good Food recommends starting with a classic mirepoix base , and scores of top chefs use ious herbs and oils and other trickery to elevate their dishes. Anchovies are good. The sauce is perfect for home cooks with little time   Food writer Felicity Cloake suggests the more classic use of olive oil in tomato sauce. She also puts in a pinch of sugar and some red wine vinegar. The thing to do is experiment. Garlic or no garlic, parsley or thyme or basil or rosemary, as long as the tinned tomatoes are good and theres parmesan on the table, we imagine people will be well fed. One things for certain, though – Marcellas advice is an ideal time-saver and perfect for amateur cooks with busy families. Andyou do decide to put tomatoes on to cook, remember: - dont boil your sauce, simmer it - add a ladle-full of pasta water to the sauce - lots of salt in the pasta water - no need for oil! If pasta sticks, its overcooked - and always add the pasta to the sauce, not the other way around

The video was filmed when -year-old Bruno visited his family in Porto Alegre, Brazil, last week. Alayde loves having her hair dyed so much she now plans to have a new colour every month. Bruno, who works in cyber security, said: She knows [she has gone viral]. She absolutely loved it. I showed to her some comments and she was really happy about it. She said that she hopes that with her going viral more people decide to take action and do whatever they want and are afraid of. Shes absolutely loving [her new hair colour]. title: mum 26 wakes up after
story: NewsMum, , wakes up after doctors failed to detect a heartbeat for  hoursShe was unconscious when she was taken to the First Affiliated Hospital of Xiamen University in Chinas eastern Fujian ProvinceShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror video women--wakes-up-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman has been a miraculous recovery in hospital despite doctors failing to detect a heartbeat for  hours. The unnamed patient was taken to the First Affiliated Hospital of Xiamen University in Chinas eastern Fujian Province. Her husband carried the -year-old over his back for emergency treatment at .pm on New Years Day as she had no heartbeat and was unconscious. Medics said she suffered from ventricular fibrillation, which is when the heart quivers instead of pumping blood around the body. She was eventually diagnosed with acute myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle. The team of doctors performed chest compressions for  minutes before switching the young woman to le-support system ECMO - extra-corporeal membrane oxygenation - replacing her heart and lung s with the device.   Doctor Yang Chengbin said: ECMO is a substitute for the patients cardiopulmonary s, allowing us to maintain her blood supply following cardiac arrest. Two hours later, however, she remained unconscious, her pupils dilated, and her vital signs failed to . By clinical standards, the woman was dead, but the doctors refused to give up. Doctor Zhang Minwei explained: I felt that her illness happened too suddenly. At  she was still in her prime, and she had no history of diseases. It was my opinion that we needed to create the conditions for even the slimmest chance of survival.  The patient was kept in hospitals Intensive Care Unit and ious other instruments were used to regulate her bodily s, including respiratory devices and renal replacement therapy. The miracle, as it has been described, happened after  hours, when her heart restored partial .By January , it was beating on its own. She is now in stable condition and is able to eat by herself. She remains in intensive care as medics continue renal therapy and help her restore fullof her limbs.   The patients husband, surnamed Tang, said: We spent the past few days crying. Now were very happy. We have a one-year-old son at home, too. This family cannot lose its mum. Doctor Zhang recalled the moment the patient finally came around. He said: She opened her eyes, so I tried speaking to her. I asked: Would you like some water  Squeeze my hand for yes. She squeezed my hand, and thats when I knew definitively that she had regained consciousness.   For the team of doctors, who have an average age of below , they have witnessed something truly remarkable. ICU medic Xu Hao said: The patient was able to respond to commands, like when we asked her to blink. Shes very lucky not to have suffered any brain damage after her ordeal. Every single le deserves our rescue efforts. What a perfect ending.

title: what really happened jonbenet ramsey
story: NewsJonBenet Ramsey: What really happened as paedophile confessesJonBenet Ramseys murder was one of the most bizarre murders of modern times and now it could finally have been solvedShareByRhian LubinSiobhan Palmer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsJonBenet Ramsay was found murdered in the basement of her home in Colorado "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts the murder that has gripped a nation for more than  years. JonBenet Ramsey was just six when she was found bludgeoned and strangled o death in the basement of her family home on Boxing Day in . And now convicted paedophile, Gary Olivia, is reported to have confessed to killing the six-year-old. The -year-old is said to have admitted to killing JonBenet by accident in letters to a school friend. The young beauty queen was found by her father the day after the family reported her missing. They had received a two-page ransom note asking for , in exchange for the child’s safe . But, eight hours later, her dad discovered his daughter’s body under a white blanket with a cord twister round her neck in the basement of their family home. Her wrists were bound and she had been gagged with duct tape. She had also suffered a fractured skull. What happened on the days before her death and who were the initial suspects   Christmas Day had been an exciting time for the Ramsey family. Father Christmas had delivered a new bike to delighted JonBenet and she tried out her present that day - it would be the last time she rode it. Along with her dad, John, mum, Patsy, and brother, Burke, who was then nine, JonBenet went for dinner at at family friends. The six-year-old was tired after her day of fun and was carried upstairs, sleeping, by her father when the family ed home later that night. This would be the last time anyone in the family saw her alive. Just eight hours later her tiny body was discovred in the basement of the family home. As the only people known to be in the house at the time of her killing, JonBenet’s parents Patsy and John were soon under suspicion.John, a computer executive, and Patsy, a former Miss West Virginia, went on CNN to insist they had nothing to do with their daughter’s tragic murder. Within two weeks of the girl’s murder, police considered her parents were unlikely to have committed the brutal crime. They were cleared of any involvement in  with the help of DNA technology. The ransom note  The ransom note discovered with JonBenets body was handwritten on pages ripped from a notepad her mother had kept by the telephone. Theories circulated suggesting the ransom note was actually written by the little girl’s mum. The sum asked for was the exact amount JonBenets father had received in his work bonus that year. Experts also claimed there was a connection in handwriting style between Patsy and the note-writer. Cina Wong examined the note for three weeks in , comparing it to examples of Patsy Ramsey’s writing. Wong claimed there were over  similarities. Suspects JonBenet’s older brother Burke was nine at the time of her murder. Theories emerged that he could be the killer and that their parents covered up JonBenet’s death to protect their son. He was cleared by DNA evidence. Around the th anniversary of JonBenets death, her brother spoke out for the first time in  on US talk show Dr. Phil. He said: “I dont know what to say to that, because I know thats not what happened.  Theres been people who have said thats not even physically possible for a nine-year-old to do that,” he said. “Like you wont find any evidence because I didnt do it.” John Ramsey revealed later how he tried to hide the allegations splashed across the papers from his young son. The headlines from a tabloid screamed out that Burke had done it, he said in . She [Patsy] dropped her produce and rushed Burke out but the damage had been done.  In  a jury voted to charge JonBenets parents with child abuse that resulted in the death of their daughter. The charges were never pursued and DNA evidence later also cleared them both. Patsy Ramsey died from oian cancer in ,  years after her daughters murder, aged . Burke Ramsey said he chose to finally speak out about his experience because: I know people think I did it that my parents did it. I know that we were suspects. I want to honour her memory by doing this interview. I dont want anyone to forget. He told Dr Phil that “I kinda always just thought it was a paedophile who saw her at one of the pageants, snuck in, who knows ” The district attorny apologised to JonBenets parents in  and exonerated them of any wrongdoing in relation to their daughters death. What other theories are there   DNA evidence taken from under JonBenets nails at the scene cleared both her parents and her brother. It revealed the little girl had probably clawed at her attacker in the strugle. But the DNA did not come from anyone who had been at the scene, her family or anyone who had handled her body. It was from an unknown male. DNA, believed to be saliva, was also found in her underwear. The intruder theory  With all of JonBenet’s family cleared of her murder, another possible explanation was that an intruder forced entry into their house and carried out the killing without anyone hearing the horric crime take place. The CBS documentary examined a broken window, which could have been used to access the basement where JonBenet was found. JonBenet’s dad said he broke the window some time before the murder when he was locked out of the house. Boulder Police Department initially ruled out anyone gaining entry through this window. But on the other side of that broken window was a suitcase, where police found a footprint.Its thought that an intruder could have possibly stepped on the suitcase to get back out of the window, leaving the footprint behind. The footprint was from a pair of Hi Tec boots, which the familys lawyer insisted that is proof that an intruder got into the house. The lawsuit  Burke Ramsey filed a lawsuit against CBS for a docu-series made in ,  years after his sisters murder.He sued the US broadcaster after their programme suggested he killed his younger sister.CBS officials requested the  million case be thrown out but a judge refused.According to Burke, his reputation was ruined after the two-part show - The case of: JonBenet Ramsey - concluded he was JonBenet’s killer.While CBS argued that the programme included a clear disclaimer which said: “The opinions and conclusions of the investigators who appear on this program about how it may have occurred represent just some of a number of possible scenarios.”However, the judge, Michigan rd Circuit Court District Judge David Groner, said that wasn’t enough to throw out Ramseys case.He added: “This Court does not find that the disclaimer at the beginning and end of the program negate the docu-series potentially defamatory meaning.”According to local paper The Daily Camera, the case has since led to courts in the Ramsey family’s hometown of Boulder, Colorado, to request vast numbers of files from the police investigation.The police are fighting the subpoena on the basis that “disclosure of police investigative files will adversely affect the investigation.The case is still in the pre-trial stage. The confession  Convicted paedophile Gary Olivia has reportedly confessed to the killing in letters sent to a former school friend. He is said to have admitted to killing the child beauty queen by accident. The -year-old is serving a -year sentence for child abuse image charges. In one of the letters, Oliva allegedly wrote: I never loved anyone like I did JonBeneacutet and yet I let her slip and her head bashed in half and I watched her die. It was an accident. Please believe me. She was not like the other kids. In another letter, Oliva is alleged to have said: Yet by accident she died and it was my fault. The Boulder Police Department is investigating.

title: dry january cannot stop these new dundee pubs becoming cornerstones of their communities
story: It may be Dry January, but pubs in Dundee are just about keeping their heads above water in the face of a pub closures sweeping across the UK.More than , pubs have closed in the UK in the last decade, while Dundee has  fewer pubs now than it did in  and , fewer jobs in the industry.However, the city remains above the national average for pubs per population, with . watering holes per , people. Nationally the figure is ..And in among the figures are the unlikely success stories of boozers brought back from the brink of extinction.The Tavern, in Whitfield, has proved that new premises are finding their feet in a challenging market.The pub opened its doors at the end of June last year.Manager Elysia Rice said the pub still plays an “important” part in bringing communities together.She said: “I’m not surprised to hear these figures. It can be a dficult market.“Competing with national chains and well-established pubs is a tough task.”Elysia, who has been in the licensed trade for more than six years, said it was harder for city centre pubs to compete.She added: “It would certainly be very challenging for a start-up pub to go into town.“Pubs can still play an important part in the community.“We’ve got a darts team in the pub and are in the process of starting a football team as well.“The older generation maybe lost a bit of that when the Whitfield Club closed its doors.“We now have a Tuesday Club which is mega busy – it’s a great place for them to meet up.”Meanwhile licensee Dale Nelson reopened the Airlie Arms this month.The -year-old has been working in licensed premises since he was .Despite the fact the bar on Dundonald Street had been shut for several months, Dale believes there is potential to turn its fortunes around.He said: “There are a lot of pubs in the city centre, the market is quite saturated.“We felt there was potential here based on the level of housing.“There are two football teams in the local area which bring in a good footfall.“We had Partick Thistle fans in here last week who had visited the VA.“I believe city centre landmarks could have a positive impact on the surrounding areas.”Dale added: “There is a small team here working to make a go of this pub.”David Glass, president of Dundee Licensed Trade Association, said pubs were still a “cornerstone” of local communities.He added: “There is definitely a feel-good factor in Dundee.“People have said there are too many hotels but these companies don’t come into a city on a whim.”David, who has owned Doc Ferry’s in Broughty Ferry since , said: “The pub is still a cornerstone of society, especially in local communities.“There is no denying businesses have maybe had their fingers burned in the past, not realising the scale of what they’ve got themselves into.“The days of someone coming in and owning a pub and leaving others to run it have probably gone now.”
